newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain will thank its military one day - Gonzalez.
newsitem.headline: Spain will thank its military one day - Gonzalez.

text.p: Socialist leader Felipe Gonzalez, in his first live interview since losing power in May, avoided questions about a "dirty war" on ETA rebels on Thursday and said Spaniards would one day thank the military for their restraint.

Looking tense and weary in the first major television appearance since the end of his 13-year rule, the former prime minister declined comment on a pending Supreme Court decision over whether to question him about the illegal 1983-87 drive against ETA, which killed 28 people.

"Spain, the democratic Spain, will thank the security forces or the armed forces with hindsight for their extraordinarily respectful and self-restrained behaviour during that period, in spite of the enormous provocations they endured," he said.
ETA (Basque Homeland and Freedom) has killed nearly 800 people in a campaign for independence begun in 1968. Civil Guard members and policemen are its favourite targets.

Gonzalez, who rejects charges by former subordinates that he authorised the "dirty war", denied being hamstrung as opposition leader but described as unfortunate his own statements last month when he labelled the 28 murders as "incidents".

Those comments, and his denial that Spain had engaged in state terrorism under his rule, prompted the new conservative government's number two to accuse him of "bodeguilla terrorism" -- a reference to the wine cellar in his official residence where he entertained friends and hatched strategies with aides.
Gonzalez declined to be drawn on this charge or on whether purported military files leaked to the local press since last year supported the "dirty war" allegations against him.
"It's not up to me to pass judgment on that," he said. "It's up to the judges, and it's in their hands."

The papers are not available to the courts because Gonzalez's successor, Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar, has turned down their requests to declassify the files -- a decision the Socialist leader praised on Thursday as a responsible move.

Gonzalez's first interior minister and a top general in the paramilitary Civil Guard are on trial in connection with the illegal series of bombings, kidnappings, torture and murder, with a one-third share of mistaken identities.
The Supreme Court is expected to announce on November 4 whether it wants to question Gonzalez about the "dirty war" as a witness, as a suspect -- or not at all.
Last year, before being forced to call early elections over mounting "dirty war" charges and corruption scandals, Gonzalez denounced in parliament an undefined conspiracy against him.
Asked on Thursday whether he believed that was still afoot, he replied: "Who knows."
